subject: Nutrition
title: Sugar and Slavery
description: A fast breakdown of Sugar and Slavery for builders.

hook.text: Sugar was called 'white gold' in the 1700s. The human cost of producing it was staggering.

buildup.text: European demand for sugar drove the slave tradeâ€”millions were enslaved to work sugar plantations.

discovery.text: Sugar went from rare luxury to daily staple in 200 years, becoming the most traded commodity in the world.

twist.text: By 1800, the average Briton ate 18 pounds of sugar yearly. Today that figure exceeds 70 pounds.

climax.text: The same crop that built colonial empires now drives a global obesity and diabetes epidemic.

punchline.text: Sugar's history is sweetness built on suffering.

quiz.question: How much sugar does the average Briton consume yearly today?
